page.title: 16CHILMARK RIDING SCHOOL
page.content: S.W. of Chilmark on the N. Slope of Kents Hill lie 8 acres of{pasture grazed by{5 ponies.}Many local children come to ride them. They love to catch, feed, groom and saddle them and clean saddlery and stables as well as ride them. One of the three fields is used for hay each year; cut and baled by a local farmer and stored in the barn for winter feed. Some loose hay is made with pitchforks and rakes. The hardy{Moorland ponies}live out all the year. Thick old hedges and a windbreak of trees provide shelter. Bridle paths between the villages must be cleared of brambles, blackthorn and nettles. Here nuts and blackberries are picted, and holly for Christmas decoration. Somestimes we have a {sponsored ride or gymkhana}for charity On Sunday the older children attend church and ride afterwards. D.L.F
